  • Portfolio

My name is Lauren Wong, and I’m a creative strategist with a background in brand strategy, design research, and innovation.

My approach, called Concept Society, specializes in bringing a future-forward perspective to all kinds of creative work. I’m currently an innovation consultant and part-time design faculty in New York.

Portfolio

  • #strategy
  • #innovation
  • #research
  • #design

‘Hooking Up Grandma’s House’ Creative Campaign (2016)

Client: XFINITY

Role: Strategist at 72andSunny

XFINITY wanted to show how technology can bring multiple generations together over the holidays, particularly grandparents and grandkids. Adweek, Creativity Online, and The Drum covered the campaign that ran across TV, social, and digital.

‘ANTIdiaRy’ Creative Campaign (2015)

Client: Samsung

Role: Strategist at 72andSunny

Samsung and Rihanna collaborated together to launch her newest album and creative endeavor - ANTI. Together with R/GA, an award-winning digital agency, and Punchdrunk, the creative minds behind Sleep No More, 72andSunny made ANTIdiaRy - an immersive mobile experience and 8-part video series based on Rihanna’s creative legacy.

ANTIdiaRy earned dozens of press mentions (like Fuse, Billboard, Elle, and Vibe) as well as thousands of mobile site visitors and a Silver Clio Award.

‘Lebron Uninterrupted’ Creative Campaign (2015)

Client: Samsung

Role: Strategist at 72andSunny

Samsung worked with Lebron James to launch the Gear VR (a virtual reality headset) along with exclusive Lebron VR content. We created a TV spot that showed what Lebron’s hometown, Cleveland, meant to his work ethic. It went on to win a Bronze Clio Award.

‘Hall of Futures’ Exhibit

Design Anthropological Futures Conference (2015)

Role: Creator and Exhibitor

The Design Anthropological Futures Conference invited me to create an exhibit and workshop in Copenhagen, Denmark during their academic conference. My three-room exhibit, called "Hall of Futures," helped design and anthropology practitioners explore future career choices.

‘Department for Communicative Beings and Things’ Exhibit (2014)

Photos: CCA, Montréal.

Canadian Centre for Architecture

Role: Designer in collaboration with Extrapolation Factory

The Extrapolation Factory, a Brooklyn-based speculative design studio, was invited by the Canadian Centre for Architecture in Montreal, Canada to create a speculative exhibit and workshop for the Centre's fall programming. For the exhibit, we invented a fictional "ministry" in a speculative future ruled by the Internet of Things. Visiting participants registered lobbying groups on behalf of newly communicative things - toasters, cars, etc. and designed bumper stickers to promote their interests.

‘The Futures Arcade’ Transdisciplinary Design MFA Thesis (2014)

Parsons the New School for Design

Role: Designer and Strategist

The Futures Arcade was a graduate thesis project co-designed by Liz Blasi, Min Chung, and myself. During the last year of our Transdisciplinary Design master's program, we worked with educators, students, design practitioners, and college counselors to explore how students think about their future. By focusing on skill development, college financial planning, and career exploration, we designed a set of strategies to help young people through these difficult decisions.

‘The Maker’s Manual’ Trends Report (2014)

Photos: PSFK

Client: Intel

Role: Researcher and Strategy Consultant

PSFK, a trends consultancy and editorial platform, collaborated with Intel to create The Maker's Manual. The comprehensive trends report examined the future of maker culture in America. I worked with a small team to identify, analyze, and report on trends shaping the maker community. The published report helped Intel connect more deeply to makers and provided greater understanding on this emerging category.

‘Digital Youth and Intellectual Property’ Research Program (2013)

Client: Ford Foundation

Role: Lead Researcher

The Ford Foundation created a fellowship that invited graduate students across India, China, and the US to collaborate on original research projects. I led a small field research team across four cities in India and China to learn how local youth explored questions of digital piracy, ownership, and intellectual property.

Teaching Engagements (2013-2016)

Parsons the New School for Design

Role:
Design Strategies Faculty
Lead Teaching Assistant
Course Coordinator

Since 2013, I’ve designed, taught, and led courses at the New School within the School of Design Strategies School. Courses covered a range of topics related to design, creativity, technology, and future planning/speculative design.

‘Inclusion and Diversity in the Creative Class’

Design Research Undergraduate Course

Throughout the semester, students practiced design research methods to explore inclusion and diversity in the creative class. The course worked with 72andSunny, The New York Times, and many other creative organizations to understand how design could play a role in building a more inclusive, vibrant community.

‘Design for This Century’

Design and Technology Graduate Course

Students in this course studied the implications and consequences of designing with technology. Throughout the semester, students learned how the fields of technology and design will change in the 21st century - and what their responsibilities as designers must be.

'Design at the Edge’

Creativity and Design Undergraduate Course

The course combined weekly lectures from over a dozen creative experts with smaller project-based learning sessions to understand how people stay creative. Students learned design research and ethnography methods to reflect on their own creative practices.

‘Creativity, Innovation, and Design’

Design Theory Graduate Course

This small graduate seminar explored how highly creative communities within design, architecture, and fashion formed. Students analyzed the shared traits and catalysts that developed major creative movements across disciplines.
